title: The Best And Worst Back Exercises (Ranked By Science)

S-Tier.setup_notes: Sit down at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Grip the bar with a wide grip, pull the bar down to your upper chest while keeping your back straight, and then slowly return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Offers a big stretch on your lats, provides smooth even tension throughout the range of motion, feels great, and allows for easy overload by increasing the pin weight.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets both the lats and mid traps due to the wide grip and pulling motion.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Neutral grip pull-downs emphasize lats over mid traps.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Sit down at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Grip the bar with a neutral grip, pull the bar down to your upper chest while keeping your back straight, and then slowly return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Similar benefits to wide grip pull-downs but with more lat emphasis.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Emphasizes the lats more due to the neutral grip.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Wide grip pull-downs for more mid trap activation.

S-Tier.exercise_name: Half Kneeling One Arm Lat Pull Down
S-Tier.setup_notes: Kneel on one knee and brace against a bench or your knee for stability.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the cable down with one arm, focusing on driving the elbow down, and return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: High stretch, high tension, good feel, and easy to overload. Allows focus on one lat at a time to prevent asymmetries.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on unilateral development.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Brace against your knee for stability.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the weight towards your hip, focusing on squeezing the midback, and return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Stretches the back significantly, provides high tension, and allows for unilateral work.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the midback with high tension and stretch.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Use a chest-supported row machine or incline bench.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your chest against the pad, and return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Stable, allows focus on back muscles, and can be done with various equipment.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets both lats and midback due to the pulling motion.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Helms rows with dumbbells if no machine is available.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Crowned as the best exercise for back development.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Sit at a cable row machine with feet braced against the platform.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the handle towards your abdomen while keeping your back straight, and return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides a deep stretch, great lat pump, and easy to progress.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch and contraction.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Wide grip shifts emphasis to mid traps.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Sit at a cable row machine with feet braced against the platform.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the wide grip handle towards your chest while keeping your back straight, and return to the starting position.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Shifts emphasis to mid traps while maintaining benefits of close grip cable rows.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets mid traps due to the wide grip and pulling motion.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Close grip for more lat emphasis.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Hang from a pull-up bar with a wide grip.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: High tension and deep stretch, but tricky resistance profile.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch and contraction.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Hang from a pull-up bar with a neutral grip.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Similar to wide grip pull-ups with more lat emphasis.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Emphasizes the lats more due to the neutral grip.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Stand on a platform to increase range of motion.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform a Pendlay row with a deeper negative.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Increased stretch on lats due to deeper negative.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with increased stretch.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a cable set at shoulder height.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the cable across your body while twisting your torso.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Increases stretch on lats but can feel awkward.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with increased stretch.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Brace against a bench for stability.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform a dumbbell row with some leg drive and momentum.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Controlled momentum assists through the range of motion.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with controlled momentum.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Perform lying on the floor or seated.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the rope towards your face while keeping your body stable.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Eliminates balancing requirement, allowing more tension on the back.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the midback with a focus on stability.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Standard face pull for less stability.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a cable set at shoulder height.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the cable down while bending forward, focusing on lats.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Huge stretch and strong mind-muscle connection.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch.
A-Tier.limitations: Triceps may take over if not performed correctly.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Lie on a bench with a dumbbell held above your chest.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the dumbbell behind your head, then pull it back to the starting position.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: High tension at the bottom, less at the top, but stretch is most anabolic.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Hang from a pull-up bar with a palms-up grip.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Shifts some back tension to biceps.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats and biceps due to the palms-up grip.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a barbell in front of you.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Bend over and pull the barbell towards your abdomen, then lower it back down.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Stretches the back well but requires stabilizing muscles.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the back with a focus on stretch.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a barbell in front of you.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Bend over and pull the barbell towards your abdomen, then lower it back down.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Higher degree of stretch and tension, but not stable enough for pure hypertrophy.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a T-bar in front of you.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the T-bar towards your chest while keeping your back straight.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Nice stretch and tension but balance can be an issue.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lats with a focus on stretch.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a cable set at shoulder height.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Pull the rope towards your face while keeping your body stable.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Stretches midback well but unstable when done conventionally.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the midback with a focus on stretch.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a barbell in front of you.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Lift the barbell from the ground to hip level, then lower it back down.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Beefs up spinal erectors but lacks active range of motion for lats and traps.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the lower back with a focus on spinal erectors.
C-Tier.limitations: Lacks active range of motion for lats and traps.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Better suited for lower body day.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Set up a bar at waist height and lie underneath it.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Pull your chest to the bar while keeping your body straight.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Amazing stretch but progression is limited.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the back with a focus on stretch.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Stand with a barbell in front of you.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Perform a barbell row with a more upright posture.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Looser form allows more weight but reduces stretch.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the back with a focus on tension.
C-Tier.limitations: Reduced stretch due to upright posture.

F-Tier.setup_notes: Start in a plank position with dumbbells in each hand.
F-Tier.execution_notes: Row one dumbbell to your side while maintaining a plank position, then switch sides.
F-Tier.tier_reasons: Lacks good stretch and tension due to balance requirements.
F-Tier.additional_notes: Crowned as the worst exercise for back hypertrophy.

F-Tier.setup_notes: Set up a barbell on a rack at knee height.
F-Tier.execution_notes: Lift the barbell from the rack to hip level, then lower it back down.
F-Tier.tier_reasons: Less range of motion than deadlift, often damages equipment.
F-Tier.limitations: Damages equipment, less range of motion.

criterias: The exercise should provide a significant stretch and maintain high tension on the targeted muscles.
The exercise should not cause pain, should have a smooth resistance profile, and should promote a good mind-muscle connection.
The exercise should allow for easy progression by adding weight or reps over time.
muscle_part_anatomy_function: Responsible for shoulder adduction, extension, and internal rotation.
Includes muscles like the rhomboids and traps, which are responsible for scapular retraction and stabilization.
Involved in moving, rotating, and stabilizing the scapula and extending the neck.
Support the spine and are involved in extending and rotating the back.
main_knowledge_summary.form_details: Wide grip pull-ups and neutral grip pull-ups provide high tension and a deep stretch, with the neutral grip emphasizing the lats more. Chin-ups shift some tension to the biceps. Wide grip lat pull-downs and neutral grip pull-downs offer smooth tension and are easily overloaded. The half-kneeling one-arm lat pull-down allows for unilateral focus and stability. Barbell rows and their variations (Yates, Pendlay, and deficit Pendlay) differ in posture and stability, affecting the stretch and tension on the lats and mid traps. Chest-supported rows provide stability, allowing focus on the back muscles. Cable rows, especially with a wide grip, emphasize the mid traps. Face pulls, when modified, improve stability and tension application. Cable lat pullovers and dumbbell pullovers focus on the stretch, with the latter having more tension at the bottom.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: The video emphasizes the importance of exercises that provide a significant stretch and maintain high tension for muscle growth. It suggests that exercises combining multiple movements (e.g., Renegade rows) may dilute tension on the target muscles. The video also highlights the importance of stability in exercises to maximize tension on the back muscles.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: To optimize back workouts, focus on exercises that provide a deep stretch and maintain high tension, such as wide grip pull-ups, lat pull-downs, and chest-supported rows. Ensure exercises feel good and allow for simple progression by adding weight or reps. Avoid exercises that combine multiple movements, as they may reduce tension on the target muscles. Consider modifying exercises like face pulls for better stability and tension application.
